text:
In J.R.R. Tolkien's epic Lord of the Rings series, power is a pervasive and multifaceted theme that underpins the narrative arc of the story. At its core, The Lord of the Rings is a exploration of the corrupting influence of power and the eternal struggle between its benevolent and malevolent manifestations.

The most obvious embodiment of power in the series is the One Ring, a golden circlet created by Sauron that grants its bearer mastery over Middle-earth. Sauron's lust for power drove him to forge the Ring in an attempt to dominate all free peoples, and it is his relentless pursuit of it that sets the entire story in motion. Throughout the tale, Tolkien illustrates how even well-intentioned individuals can become seduced by the promise of the Ring's authority, (Frodo), and how those who covet it most, such as Boromir,and especially Sm√©agol/(Gollum)), succumb utterly to its dark allure.

Beyond the Ring, lies the power dynamics between different groups within Middle-earth: Elves versus Dwarves, Humans against Rohan, the free kingdom vs. the darkness of Mordor, Isengard versus Minas Tirith, to cite but a few salient examples.
